sen.j: 舎人親王（とねりしんのう、天武天皇4年1月5日 (旧暦)（676年1月28日） - 天平7年11月14日 (旧暦)（735年12月6日））は天武天皇皇子。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Toneri (Toneri Shinno) (January 5, 675 (old lunar calendar) (February 8, 675) - November 14, 735 (old lunar calendar) (December 6, 735) was an prince of Emperor Tenmu.
Imperial Prince Toneri (Toneri Shinno) (January 5, 675 (old lunar calendar) (February 8, 675) - November 14, 735 (old lunar calendar) (December 6, 735) was an prince of Emperor Tenmu.
Imperial Prince Toneri (February 8, 675 - December 6, 735) was a prince of Emperor Tenmu.
sen.cmt: 旧暦などを削除しました。

sen.j: 諡は崇道尽敬皇帝（すどうじんけいこうてい）。
sen.e: His posthumous name was Sudojinkei Kotei (Emperor Sudojinkei).
His posthumous name was Sudojinkei Kotei (Emperor Sudojinkei).
His posthumous name was Sudojinkei Kotei (Emperor Sudojinkei).

sen.j: 淳仁天皇の父である。
sen.e: He was Emperor Junnin's father.
He was Emperor Junnin's father.
He was Emperor Junnin's father.

sen.j: 奈良時代初期に長屋王とともに皇親勢力として権勢をふるった。
sen.e: In the early Nara Period, he exerted power as a member of the imperial family together with Nagayao (Prince Nagaya).
In the early Nara Period, he exerted power as a member of the imperial family together with Nagayao (Prince Nagaya).
In the early Nara period, he exerted power as a member of the Imperial Family together with Prince Nagaya.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 日本書紀の編集も総裁した。
sen.e: He supervised the compilation of "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan)
He supervised the compilation of "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan)
He supervised the compilation of "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).
sen.cmt: ピリオド補足しました。

sen.j: 舎人皇子（とねりのみこ）とも言う。
sen.e: Also called Toneri no miko.
Also called Toneri no miko.
Also called Toneri no miko.

sen.j: 天武天皇4年1月5日生まれ。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Toneri was born on February 8, 675.
Imperial Prince Toneri was born on February 8, 675.
Imperial Prince Toneri was born on February 8, 675.

sen.j: 父は天武天皇、母は天智天皇皇女新田部皇女である。
sen.e: His father was Emperor Tenmu, and mother was Princess Nitabe, a daughter of Emperor Tenchi.
His father was Emperor Tenmu, and his mother was Princess Nitabe, a daughter of Emperor Tenchi.
His father was Emperor Tenmu, and his mother was Princess Nitabe, a daughter of Emperor Tenchi.

sen.j: 妻は当麻山背。
sen.e: His wife was TAIMA no Yamashiro.
His wife was TAIMA no Yamashiro.
His wife was TAIMA no Yamashiro.

sen.j: 子に三原王、三島王、船王、池田王、守部王、御浦王、大炊王（後の淳仁天皇）などがいる。
sen.e: His sons include Princes Mihara, Mishima, Fune, Ikeda, Moribe, Miura and Oi (later Emperor Junnin).
His sons include Princes Mihara, Mishima, Fune, Ikeda, Moribe, Miura, and Oi (later Emperor Junnin).
His sons include Princes Mihara, Mishima, Fune, Ikeda, Moribe, Miura, and Oi (later Emperor Junnin).
sen.cmt: 不要な改行を削除しました。

sen.j: 疫病に倒れたとは言え、天武天皇の皇子のなかで最後まで生き残り、長命を得た人物である。
sen.e: Although he was plagued, he survived and lived longest among the sons of Emperor Tenmu.
Although he was suffered plague, he survived and lived longest among the sons of Emperor Tenmu.
Although he was suffered plague, he survived and lived longest among the sons of Emperor Tenmu.

sen.j: 三原王の孫に清原夏野、また、子孫に清原深養父・清少納言がいる。
sen.e: A grandson of Prince Mihara was KIYOHARA no Natsuno, and his descendants include KIYOHARA no Fukayabu and Sei Shonagon.
A grandson of Prince Mihara was KIYOHARA no Natsuno, and his descendants include KIYOHARA no Fukayabu and Sei Shonagon.
A grandson of Prince Mihara was KIYOHARA no Natsuno, and his descendants include KIYOHARA no Fukayabu and Sei Shonagon.

sen.j: 清原氏は高市皇子・長屋王系列の高階氏共々天武系後裔氏族として長く血脈が続いた。
sen.e: The Kiyohara clan, together with the Takashina clan of the line of Prince Takechi and Prince Nagaya, lasted generation after generation as descendants of Emperor Tenmu.
The Kiyohara clan, together with the Takashina clan of the line of Prince Takechi and Prince Nagaya, lasted generation after generation as descendants of Emperor Tenmu.
The Kiyohara clan, together with the Takashina clan of the line of Prince Takechi and Prince Nagaya, lasted generation after generation as descendants of Emperor Tenmu.

sen.j: 養老2年（718年）、一品の位階に昇叙され、翌養老3年には元正天皇より異母弟の新田部親王と共に皇太子首皇子の補佐を命じられた。
sen.e: In 718 he was promoted to Ippon (First Order of an Imperial Prince) and in the following 719 he and his half brother Imperial Prince Niitabe were ordered by the Empress Gensho to support Crown Prince Obito.

In 718 he was promoted to Ippon (First Order of an Imperial Prince) and in the following year, 719, he and his half brother Imperial Prince Niitabe were ordered by the Empress Gensho to support Crown Prince Obito.

In 718 he was promoted to Ippon (First Order of an Imperial Prince) and in the following year, 719, he and his younger paternal half-brother Imperial Prince Niitabe were ordered by the Empress Gensho to support Crown Prince Obito.
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせました。

sen.j: 養老4年（720年）5月には『日本書紀』を奏上している。
sen.e: In May 720 (old lunar calendar), he presented "Nihonshoki" to the throne.
In May 720 (old lunar calendar), he presented "Nihonshoki" to the throne.
In June, 720, he presented "Nihonshoki" to the throne.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に直しました。

sen.j: 同年8月、実力者であった右大臣藤原不比等薨去に伴い知太政官事に就任、右大臣（後、左大臣）の長屋王とともに皇親政権を樹立する。
sen.e: When a powerful Minister of the Right FUJIWARA no Fuhito died in August 720 (old lunar calendar), Prince Toneri was appointed to Deputy Prime Minister and established the administration of imperial family together with the Minister of the Right (later of the Left) Prince Nagaya.

When a powerful Minister of the Right, FUJIWARA no Fuhito, died in August 720 (old lunar calendar), Prince Toneri was appointed Deputy Prime Minister and established the administration of the imperial family together with the Minister of the Right (later of the Left) Prince Nagaya.

When a powerful Minister of the Right, FUJIWARA no Fuhito, died in September of the same year, Prince Toneri was appointed Deputy Prime Minister and established the administration of the Imperial Family together with the Minister of the Right (later of the Left) Prince Nagaya.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に直しました。

sen.j: 神亀1年（724年）聖武天皇（首皇子）即位に際し、封500戸を加えられている。
sen.e: When Emperor Shomu (Prince Obito) ascended the throne in 724, Prince Toneri received additional 500 vassal households.
When Emperor Shomu (Prince Obito) ascended the throne in 724, Prince Toneri received 500 additional vassal households.
When Emperor Shomu (Prince Obito) ascended the throne in 724, Prince Toneri received 500 additional vassal households.

sen.j: 舎人皇子は次第に藤原氏寄りに傾斜し、天平1年（729年）2月に起こった長屋王の変では新田部親王と共に長屋王を糾問し、自害せしめた。
sen.e: Prince Toneri gradually became closer to the Fujiwara clan, and when the Conspiracy of Prince Nagaya occurred in February 729 (old lunar calendar) he and Prince Niitabe denounced Prince Nagaya and made him commit suicide.

Prince Toneri gradually became closer to the Fujiwara clan, and when the Conspiracy of Prince Nagaya occurred in February 729 (old lunar calendar) he and Prince Niitabe denounced Prince Nagaya and made him commit suicide.

Imperial Prince Toneri gradually became closer to the Fujiwara clan, and when the Conspiracy of Prince Nagaya occurred in March 729 he and Imperial Prince Niitabe denounced Prince Nagaya and made him commit suicide.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に直し、統一リストに合わせました。

sen.j: 同年8月には藤原氏出身の光明皇后の立后を宣言するなど藤原四兄弟政権の成立に協力した。
sen.e: In August of the same year, Prince Toneri announced the investiture of the Empress Komyo who came from the Fujiwara clan to cooperate in the establishment of the administration of four brothers of Fujiwara clan.

In August of the same year, Prince Toneri announced the investiture of the Empress Komyo, who came from the Fujiwara clan to cooperate in the establishment of the administration of four brothers of Fujiwara clan.

In September of the same year, Imperial Prince Toneri announced the investiture of the Empress Komyo, who came from the Fujiwara clan to cooperate in the establishment of the administration of four brothers of Fujiwara clan.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に直し、統一リストに合わせました。

sen.j: 天平7年（735年）11月14日、天然痘が蔓延する平城京で60歳の生涯を閉じ、太政大臣を贈位される。
sen.e: He died on December 6, 735 in the smallpox-ridden capital of Heijokyo, and the Grand Minister was conferred on him.
He died on December 6, 735 in the smallpox-ridden capital of Heijokyo, and the title Grand Minister was conferred on him.
He died on December 6, 735 in the smallpox-ridden capital of Heijo-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Nara), and the title Grand Minister was conferred on him.

sen.j: 天平宝字3年（759年）、大炊王が淳仁天皇として即位するに及び、天皇の父として崇道尽敬皇帝と追号された。
sen.e: In 759 when Prince Oi ascended the throne as Emperor Junnin, a posthumous title Sudoujinkei Kotei (Emperor Sudojinkei) was given as the father of the Emperor.
In 759, when Prince Oi ascended the throne as Emperor Junnin, Prince Toneri was given a posthumous title Sudoujinkei Kotei (Emperor Sudojinkei) as the father of the Emperor.
In 759, when Prince Oi ascended the throne as Emperor Junnin, Imperial Prince Toneri was given a posthumous title Sudoujinkei Kotei (Emperor Sudojinkei) as the father of the Emperor.
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせました。

sen.j: 墓所は、奈良県奈良市田中町にある黄金塚陵墓参考地が候補地とされていたが、2009年2月の発掘調査により、別人のものと判明した。
sen.e: Although it had been assumed that his grave was Koganezuka referable mausoleum in Tanaka-cho, Nara City, Nara Prefecture, the excavation research in February 2009 revealed that the mausoleum was someone else's grave.

Although it had been assumed that his grave was Koganezuka referable mausoleum in Tanaka-cho, Nara City, Nara Prefecture, excavation research conducted in February 2009 revealed that the mausoleum was someone else's grave.

Although it had been assumed that his grave was Koganezuka referable mausoleum in Tanaka-cho, Nara City, Nara Prefecture, excavation research conducted in February 2009 revealed that the mausoleum was someone else's grave.

sen.j: 父：天武天皇

Father: Emperor Tenmu
Father: Emperor Tenmu

sen.j: 大夫人：当麻山背（父：当麻老）
sen.e: Taifujin (a title of respect for an Emperor's mother): TAIMA no Yamashiro (Father: TAIMA no Oyu)
Taifujin (a title of respect for an Emperor's mother): TAIMA no Yamashiro (Father: TAIMA no Oyu)
Taifujin (a title of respect for an Emperor's mother): TAIMA no Yamashiro (Father: TAIMA no Oyu)

sen.e: Prince Oi (Emperor Junnin) (733 - 765)
Prince Oi (Emperor Junnin) (733 - 765)

sen.j: 飛鳥田女王（? - 782）
sen.e: Princess Asukada (? - 782)

sen.j: 万葉集に3首の歌が残る歌人でもある。
sen.e: Prince Toneri was also a poet and his three poems were selected in Manyoshu (the first major anthology of early Japanese poetry).
Prince Toneri was also a poet, and three of his poems were selected in Manyoshu (the first major anthology of early Japanese poetry).
Imperial Prince Toneri was also a poet, and three of his poems were selected in Manyoshu (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves).
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせました。

sen.j: また、柿本人麻呂歌集に、親王に献上された5首の歌が残されており、交流の跡が偲ばれる。
sen.e: KAKINOMOTO no Hitomaro's Collection includes five poems dedicated to Prince Toneri as reminders of their friendship.
KAKINOMOTO no Hitomaro's Collection includes five poems dedicated to Prince Toneri as reminders of their friendship.
KAKINOMOTO no Hitomaro's Collection includes five poems dedicated to Imperial Prince Toneri as reminders of their friendship.
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせました。

sen.j: また、賞金をかけておもしろい歌を作れといった題詞もあり、文雅を愛するひとであったと思われる。
sen.e: There is an indication that the prince offered Hitomaro a reward for an interesting poem, so he loved poetry.
There is an indication that the prince offered Hitomaro a reward for an interesting poem, so he loved poetry.
There is an indication that the imperial prince offered Hitomaro a reward for an interesting poem, so he loved poetry.

sen.j: 親王の歌を一首を紹介する。
sen.e: Here is a poem of Prince Toneri:
Here is a poem of Prince Toneri:
Here is a poem of Imperial Prince Toneri:
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせました。

sen.j: ぬば玉の夜霧ぞ立てる衣手の高屋の上にたなびくまでに （巻9）
sen.e: In the glistening Bead-black night the mists have risen Till they drift in bands On the heights of Takaya, Mountain of the garment sleeve. (Volume 9)
In the glistening Bead-black night the mists have risen Till they drift in bands On the heights of Takaya, Mountain of the garment sleeve. (Volume 9)
In the glistening Bead-black night the mists have risen Till they drift in bands On the heights of Takaya, Mountain of the garment sleeve. (Volume 9)
